author: By Eric Grode
title: The Smart Set Sneered, but the Play Won the Day
description: One hundred years ago this month, the interfaith marriage comedy “Abie’s Irish Rose” kicked off a five-year Broadway run — critics be damned.
content: Among the waspish regulars of the Algonquin Round Table, Robert Benchley cut a relatively docile figure. His drollery tended toward the observational, and his enemies were typically along the lines of dachshunds or babies or “people from Dubuque.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: In an Uphill Year, Democrats of All Stripes Worry About Electability
description: Democratic primaries in coming weeks will point to tensions within the party on how to push effectively for change, while winning elections.
content: On Monday night, several left-leaning congressional candidates joined an emergency organizing call with activists reeling from a draft Supreme Court ruling overturning Roe v. Wade. A somber Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, opening the discussion, acknowledged that Democrats held control in Washington but were nonetheless “in an uphill battle for change.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Leaky Supreme Court Starts to Resemble the Other Branches
description: The disclosure of a draft opinion that would overrule Roe v. Wade, legal experts said, was evidence that the court is not much different from other Washington institutions.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court used to be a magisterial temple of silence, capable of guarding its secrets until it was ready to disclose them. It leaked less than intelligence agencies, old hands in Washington would say, in a tone of awe and envy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: U.S. lawmakers struggle with how to get a Covid aid package passed over an immigration fight.
description: The White House has pushed for a $22.5 billion package at home and abroad, warning about the dire consequences of inaction. But a smaller package of $10 billion has been stalled in the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers on Capitol Hill continue to struggle with how to advance a pandemic aid package amid an election-year dispute over immigration, even as Congress barrels toward swift approval of $40 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: Striking a Balance Between Art and Motorcycle Maintenance
description: J. Shia, the owner of Madhouse Motors in Boston, repairs and refurbishes vintage bikes, but she also creates motorcycle sculptures shown in exhibits.
content: J. Shia first drove a motorcycle when she was about 8. Because she was small, her dad — a jack-of-all-trades with a penchant for bikes — would kick-start it for her and lean it up against a tree so she could climb up and ride. This worked well until it was time to stop the bike and get off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: 4 Takeaways From Tuesday’s Primaries in Nebraska and West Virginia
description: It was a mixed night for Trump-endorsed candidates, with fresh evidence of an urban-rural divide within the G.O.P.
content: A federal candidate backed by former President Donald J. Trump won a contested primary for the second consecutive week on Tuesday, as Representative Alex Mooney resoundingly defeated Representative David McKinley in West Virginia in the first incumbent-vs.-incumbent primary race of 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Luke Broadwater
title: House Votes to Extend Union Organizing Protections to Its Staff
description: The resolution will for the first time give House aides the same legal protections for collective bargaining enjoyed by other workers.
content: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Tuesday to grant its aides the legal protections to form a union, the most significant step in more than a quarter-century to ensure that the chamber’s staff members can bargain over their working conditions without fear of retaliation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Makulec
title: I Lost My Baby. Then Antivaxxers Made My Pain Go Viral.
description: There’s a human toll to misinformation.
content: I was one of many women who had a pandemic baby. Few people saw me pregnant, and even fewer met my second-born son, or ever will. In September 2021, just shy of 3 months of age, my son died. He was one of the most bright-eyed, happiest babies I’ve met and spent every day of his short life loved and adored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: The Mundane Thrill of ‘Romanticizing Your Life’
description: A trend that took off early in the pandemic encourages people to appreciate life’s simple pleasures, a philosophy that resonates just as strongly two years later.
content: On YouTube, a filmmaker from Utah soaks in the morning sun, savors a fresh croissant and spritzes lemon-scented perfume on a duvet decorated with pink roses. Her videos, a cozy escape into cottagecore, are inspired by “Anne of Green Gables,” Jane Austen novels and the period drama “Bridgerton,” offering tips on “how to be happier and appreciate the little things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Kyrie Irving Wants the Nets, but Do the Nets Want Him?
description: Brooklyn needs its star guard to be more than a part-time player next season, General Manager Sean Marks said, without clearly stating the team wants Irving back.
content: As the Nets’ disappointing season reached its end after they were swept by the Boston Celtics in the first round of the Eastern Conference playoffs, Kyrie Irving made clear that he was committed to the Nets for the long term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Manchester City Had the Money. Haaland’s Team Had the Plan.
description: A carefully crafted strategy for a young striker’s career paid off handsomely for him and his agents. But will everyone get what they want out of the deal?
content: A few days before last summer’s transfer window drew to a close, a handful of Manchester City’s most senior executives gathered in a conference room at the club’s sprawling campus to pick through what had gone right, and what had gone wrong, over the previous couple of months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Disney+ adds more subscribers than expected, weeks after Netflix’s count fell.
description: New releases like Pixar’s “Turning Red” helped the service surpass analyst estimates for new subscribers globally.
content: Disney+ added 7.9 million subscribers in the most recent quarter for a total of 138 million worldwide, the company announced Wednesday, helping it avoid the streaming slowdown that has lately tanked the stock price of Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Ballet, Parks, Mental Health Crisis
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to glimpse into the daily life of a professional dancer, share what parks mean to them, watch a film about teenagers’ mental health, write about an image and learn about Hungary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Angels Rookie Throws No-Hitter in Wild Blowout of Rays
description: Reid Detmers faced only one batter more than the minimum in a game that went comically sideways for Tampa Bay.
content: It takes a lot to swing the Los Angeles Angels’ spotlight away from Shohei Ohtani and Mike Trout. You might even say it takes something like a changeup — the pitch Reid Detmers, a rookie left-hander, threw so spectacularly in no-hitting the Tampa Bay Rays in Angel Stadium on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Spinal Fluid From Young Mice Sharpened Memories of Older Rodents
description: Researchers identified a protein in the fluid that could boost the cognition of aging animals — and might lead to future treatments for people.
content: Five years ago, Tal Iram, a young neuroscientist at Stanford University, approached her supervisor with a daring proposal: She wanted to extract fluid from the brain cavities of young mice and to infuse it into the brains of older mice, testing whether the transfers could rejuvenate the aging rodents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: The Strange Afterlife of George Carlin
description: Nearly 14 years after his death, his provocative humor has been embraced by people across the political spectrum. What happens when comedy outlasts the era it was made for?
content: In the closing monologue from a recent episode of his HBO talk show, Bill Maher cataloged a series of social conditions that he suggested were hampering stand-up comedy and imperiling free speech: cancel culture, a perceived increase of sensitivity on college campuses, and Will Smith slapping Chris Rock at the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Somers
title: Young Women and Their ‘Unfinished Business’
description: Debut novels expose dangerous, psychologically twisted, almost gothic sides of sex.
content: Melissa Chadburn’s debut, A TINY UPWARD SHOVE (342 pp., Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27), begins with an aswang, a shape-shifting spirit from Filipino folklore. Out for blood — it must eat flesh to remain immortal — the spirit enters the body of Marina, a murdered 18-year-old prostitute in Vancouver, to continue her “unfinished business” by taking revenge on her killer. From there the book flashes back to Marina’s childhood, working its way forward through many abuses, narrated always by the spirit, who is part Marina and part foulmouthed, roving consciousness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘The Village House’ Review: A Family and the Walls That Enfold It
description: Over two decades, babies are born, elders die, young people move on, but a home remains, even though visitors dwindle.
content: In “The Village House,” the four sides of the camera frame find beautiful, painterly pockets of space and time within the four walls of an ancestral home. Achal Mishra’s feature debut, set in Madhopur, a village in east India’s Bihar state, unfolds as a kind of autobiography — a decades-spanning portrait of the director’s family, drawn from childhood memories — and also a biography, of the abode that came before him and whose legacy will outlast him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Téa Kvetenadze
title: Man Dead and Officer Wounded After a Chase in the Bronx
description: Rameek Smith, 25, was shot in the head after he shot an officer in the arm during an exchange of gunfire, the New York Police Department said.
content: Neighbors said a man fatally shot by the police during an exchange of gunfire Tuesday night that also wounded an officer was troubled but seemed unthreatening, living under the supervision of a mental health court after a weapons charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan, Anthony Cotsifas and Leilin Lopez-Toledo
title: On Strawberry Fanta and Other Treats Imbued With Divine Status
description: Whether because of religion, fad dieting or Instagram, humans have long made food offerings in the hope of connecting with the sublime.
content: HERE IS A bottle of strawberry Fanta, candy red and gleaming like a liquefied Ferrari. Pop the cap and the fizz is brief, bestowing neither blessing nor enlightenment. Yet in Thailand, this soda — descended from a concoction of apple scraps and whey, improvised in Nazi Germany during the Second World War as a substitute for Coca-Cola — is one of the most popular offerings to make to the spirits who walk our world, only occasionally glimpsed by human eyes. Bring a bottle, unsipped, to a little spirit house, any of the countless across the country perched on sidewalks and outside homes, beauty salons and McDonald’s alike, and leave a straw poking out. The spirits will come, and maybe they will be pleased and protect you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Man Killed His Mother at Sea to Inherit Family’s Estate, U.S. Says
description: Federal prosecutors contend that during a fishing trip in 2016, Nathan Carman, 28, murdered Linda Carman, sank his boat and was adrift at sea on a life raft for eight days before being rescued.
content: A Vermont man lured his mother on a fishing trip off the coast of Rhode Island in 2016, killed her and sank the boat in a scheme to inherit his family’s estate, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: I’ve Always Struggled With My Weight. Losing It Didn’t Mean Winning.
description: A diet app helped me shed my extra Covid pounds — and reminded me that I’m still the same old me.
content: There were a few bad moments, over the course of a few bad months, that led me to download the weight-loss app. These will probably sound trivial to anyone who is not me, and of course they are trivial — but we are talking about bodies here, and about my body in particular, and one of the defining features of having a body is that it is a fire hose of tiny humiliations blasting you constantly in the face, never allowing you to look away, even when you most want to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Patrick Kingsley
title: Al Jazeera Journalist Is Killed in West Bank
description: The network and Palestinian authorities blamed Israeli troops for the killing. Israel said the blame could lie with Palestinian gunmen.
content: JERUSALEM — A journalist for Al Jazeera was fatally shot in the West Bank city of Jenin early Wednesday, the news network and the Palestinian Health Ministry said, blaming Israeli forces for her death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Louisiana’s governor says he opposes a bill to classify abortion as homicide.
description: Gov. John Bel Edwards said he would veto legislation that, if passed, would make it possible for prosecutors to bring criminal cases against women who end a pregnancy.
content: Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana signaled his opposition on Wednesday to pending legislation that would classify abortion as homicide and make it possible for prosecutors to bring criminal cases against women who end a pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: War and Weather Sent Food Prices Soaring. Now, China’s Harvest Is Uncertain.
description: Ukraine’s wheat exports have been mostly halted since Russia’s invasion, while drought has damaged crops in India and the United States. China’s upcoming harvest is another concern.
content: PINGGU, China — From village to village, the wheat crops in China have been inconsistent this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Comic or Graphic, Shows About Abortion Surface a Stark Divide
description: Decidedly anti-sensationalistic, Alison Leiby’s shrewd and funny personal monologue plays downtown. Uptown, a staged reading focuses on a gruesome case.
content: A few nights after the leak of the Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn the right to abortion protected by Roe v. Wade, the comedian Alison Leiby walked onto the stage of the Cherry Lane Theater, in Manhattan’s West Village, to greet the audience before her monologue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Gardening Shouldn’t Be Painful. Here’s How to Avoid Common Injuries.
description: “GardenFit,” a new public television series, shows that gardeners need as much attention as their plants.
content: If you want to garden smarter, you can invest in any number of tools — a telescoping pole pruner that extends your reach so you don’t have to strain quite as much, for example, or a kneeling pad with thicker cushioning. But the investment that really matters is in the most important tool of all: your body. And that requires forming new habits based on an awareness of how your body works when you’re gardening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: New Zealand will fully reopen its borders at the end of July.
description: The move comes two months ahead of schedule, in an attempt to speed up economic recovery.
content: New Zealand will fully reopen its borders at the end of July, according to a government announcement on Wednesday that noted the move comes two months ahead of schedule in an attempt to speed up the nation’s economic recovery from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Color and the Brain: Are We All Simply Puppets of the Color Palette?

author: By Lily Goldberg
title: The Bachelor Comes to Bushwick
description: A new YouTube reality series, inspired by the ABC franchise, offers willing young singles the chance at a fairy tale ending.
content: Jessica Callaghan, 30, was scrolling through Instagram when an advertisement offered her a boyfriend. “There is no substitute for true love!” it read. “Find it today with Elan! ‘The Bushwick Bachelor!’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Offers a More Modest Vision of the Future
description: Artificial intelligence is being woven into an array of the company’s products. But the change — for now — is subtle.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — There was a time when Google offered a wondrous vision of the future, with driverless cars, augmented-reality eyewear, unlimited storage of emails and photos, and predictive texts to complete sentences in progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Passenger Lands Small Plane in Florida After Pilot Falls Ill
description: “My pilot has gone incoherent, and I have no idea how to fly the airplane,” the passenger of a Cessna told air traffic control Tuesday afternoon.
content: A passenger without any flying experience safely landed a private plane on Tuesday at a Florida airport after the pilot had a medical issue, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Naomi Osaka Takes Control of Her Business Interests Off the Tennis Court
description: Already the world’s top-earning female athlete, Osaka is leaving IMG to start a sports representation company with her longtime agent, Stuart Duguid.
content: The tennis career of Naomi Osaka, one of the biggest sports celebrities in the world, has taken on certain familiar characteristics during the past 16 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Lorie Logan, a Fed veteran, will lead the Dallas Fed.
description: Ms. Logan will lead a central bank district that encompasses Texas, northern Louisiana and southern New Mexico starting in August.
content: Lorie K. Logan, a longtime Federal Reserve Bank of New York veteran, will be the next leader of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: ‘1973’ Merch: How a Year Became Shorthand for Abortion Rights
description: On “S.N.L.” or at rallies, gear with the date signals support for Roe v. Wade.
content: The story of the women’s movement during the Trump era cannot be told without clothing: There was the knitted pussy hat, the white suffragist suit, the “Future Is Female” T-shirt and the Lingua Franca sweater, all of which now fall somewhere between important cultural artifact and mockable meme, depending on who you’re talking to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Wailoo
title: How the Tobacco Industry Hooked Black Smokers on Menthols
description: The proposed ban on menthol cigarettes, long aimed at Black consumers, is crucial to reducing smoking, especially among young people.
content: As regulation of the tobacco industry has grown more and more extensive in recent decades, menthol cigarettes have been an exception. They account for more than one-third of cigarette sales in the United States and are especially dangerous because the menthol enhances nicotine’s already potent addictive effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Bitcoin Is Increasingly Acting Like Just Another Tech Stock
description: The cryptocurrency’s plunging value has mirrored losses in the Nasdaq, a benchmark that’s weighted toward tech stocks.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Bitcoin was conceived more than a decade ago as “digital gold,” a long-term store of value that would resist broader economic trends and provide a hedge against inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Teetering Government Breathes Again as Arab Party Rejoins
description: A small Islamist party decided to end its freeze on participating in the fragile eight-way coalition, granting it at least a temporary reprieve.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel’s teetering governing coalition was granted at least a temporary reprieve from its latest crisis on Wednesday when one of its partners, a small Islamist party, agreed to rejoin the coalition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘The Vagrant Trilogy’ Review: Palestinians in Exile, Yearning for Home
description: Mona Mansour’s rich trilogy, now at the Public Theater, follows a displaced Palestinian family.
content: The matinee audience was filing out of the Public Theater’s LuEsther Hall the other afternoon when stagehands started dismantling the set — a rickety home in a refugee camp in Lebanon, where Mona Mansour’s border-crossing, alternate-realities epic “The Vagrant Trilogy” winds up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Top Democrats Want Tom Suozzi Out of Governor’s Race. He’s Still Running.
description: In the New York Democratic primary, Representative Tom Suozzi is fighting Gov. Kathy Hochul for moderate voters, with a focus on fighting crime and cutting taxes.
content: Representative Thomas R. Suozzi is not the kind of person to be swayed by the advice of fellow Democrats. But as he runs for governor of New York this year, he sure has gotten his share.

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Family Ties
description: What distinguishes the few Republicans willing to confront Donald Trump?
content: Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader, was so appalled by Donald Trump’s role in the Jan. 6 attack that he signaled to colleagues shortly afterward that he was open to convicting Trump in an impeachment trial — and barring him from holding office again. A month later, however, McConnell voted to acquit him.

content: If you know a collector, you know about how collections are more than just agglomerations of items. They are stores of history, stores of emotion. They have a representational value that often far exceeds their literal financial value.

author: By Patrick Kingsley

description: Israeli soldiers had long denied killing prisoners after capturing an Arab seaside town, days after Israel’s creation. A new film provides fresh evidence — reopening a debate about Israel’s foundational story.

description: The final decision on the map, which would give Republicans a considerable advantage in the state, could ultimately lie with the State Supreme Court.

description: Antibody levels rose in the children who received it, suggesting the vaccine protects against infection. But the data were gathered before the arrival of Omicron.
content: Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine elicits a strong immune response in children aged 6 to 11, researchers reported on Wednesday — another signpost in what has become a long and tortuous road to protecting young children against the virus, even as cases again inch upward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: How abortion is already animating the Senate race in Georgia.
description: Raphael D. Warnock is one of the most vulnerable Democrats in the coming midterm elections.
content: ATLANTA — Democrats are painting a future with limited abortion access as a Republican-manufactured problem, underlined by the Senate’s failure to advance a bill to codify the terms of Roe v. Wade.

title: Rivian affirms its 2022 E.V. production goal despite supply problems.

title: Los Angeles Mayor’s Path to U.S. Ambassadorship Is Constricting
description: Mayor Eric Garcetti’s political future is unclear after a Senate report determined that he “more likely than not” knew about sexual harassment accusations against a top aide.
content: LOS ANGELES — For nearly a year, the mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, has been “between two worlds,” as he put it in an interview, waiting to be confirmed as the Biden administration’s ambassador to India while the high-stakes race to succeed him plays out in the nation’s second-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Carbone Partners Plan a Members-Only Club in New York
description: The latest outpost of Major Food Group’s exclusive ZZ’s Club, to open in Hudson Yards by year’s end, will feature a private edition of Carbone restaurant.
content: Building on the success of their members-only ZZ’s Club in Miami, Jeff Zalaznick, Mario Carbone and Rich Torrisi of Major Food Group are planning a New York City location.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: After Nude Jesse Williams Video, Theater Turns Camera on Audience
description: Despite an attempt to ban smartphones in the theater, a video of the actor’s nude scene in the Broadway production of “Take Me Out” circulated widely online.
content: The nonprofit theater presenting a starry Broadway revival of “Take Me Out” installed a new infrared camera on Wednesday to help its security team spot surreptitious camera usage by audience members after a video of a nude scene featuring the actor Jesse Williams circulated online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Can Donald Trump Get This 26-Year-Old Elected to Congress?
description: Bo Hines, a leading candidate in a Republican House primary next week in North Carolina, has little political experience but holds major campaign advantages, including money and powerful backers.
content: In Ohio, Donald Trump yanked J.D. Vance out of third place to win the Republican Senate primary. In a West Virginia House race last night, Trump catapulted a longtime Maryland politician over the choice of the state’s sitting governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Report Catalogs Abuse of Native American Children at Former Government Schools
description: Interior Secretary Deb Haaland called for a review last year, after the discovery of hundreds of unmarked graves of children who attended similar schools in Canada.
content: An initial investigation commissioned by Interior Secretary Deb Haaland cataloged some of the brutal conditions that Native American children endured at more than 400 boarding schools that the federal government forced them to attend between 1819 and 1969. The inquiry was an initial step, Ms. Haaland said, toward addressing the “intergenerational trauma” that the policy left behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Emily Cochrane
title: The Senate confirms Philip Jefferson as a Fed governor.
description: Lawmakers have now confirmed three of Mr. Biden’s nominees to the seven-person Fed Board of Governors in Washington.
content: Philip N. Jefferson, a college administrator and academic economist, was confirmed to the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Maggots: A Revolting Medical Rebirth
description: We are honoring the top eight winners of our Student STEM Writing Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Rahul Koppisetti.
content: This essay, by Rahul Koppisetti, 16, from Livingston High School in Livingston, N.J., is one of the top eight winners of The Learning Network’s third annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,564 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Broadway’s Best Perform for The Times
description: Billy Crystal, Shoshana Bean and performers from “Company,” “MJ,” “A Strange Loop,” “Six” and other Tony-nominated shows will share songs and stories.
content: The 2022 Tony Awards nominations make clear that Broadway’s reopening season has been anything but dull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Ron DeSantis Is Being Incoherent on Inflation
description: The Florida governor, like many other Republicans, needs to get his story straight.
content: Some of the very people who blame President Biden for causing inflation by overstimulating the economy are pressing for or making tax cuts that would stimulate the economy even more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Shane Goldmacher and Reid J. Epstein
title: Hard-Liners Gain in Pennsylvania G.O.P. Races, Worrying Both Parties
description: Doug Mastriano and Kathy Barnette are amplifying Donald Trump’s stolen-election lie in two key races. Republicans fear they could lose in November. Democrats fear they could win.
content: ERIE, Pa. — Republican voters in Pennsylvania, one of the nation’s most hotly contested political battlegrounds, appear to be rallying behind two hard-right candidates for governor and the Senate who are capturing grass-roots anger, railing against the party’s old guard and amplifying Donald Trump’s stolen-election myth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: James Corden Calls Trump a ‘Scam Account’
description: Corden joked that “banning Trump is like the one good thing Twitter has done in like a decade.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Artists of Color and Women Soar at Christie’s ‘21st Century’ Sale
description: Because of strong demand, young artists’ typically long journey to the world stages has been accelerated.
content: While the usual suspects continue to command the highest prices at auction — as evidenced by Monday night’s $195 million sale of Warhol’s “Marilyn” — the art market also continues to seize on the potential next hot thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: Judge Lifts Contempt Order Against Trump in Civil Inquiry
description: The former president must pay a $110,000 fine that accumulated during the two-week contempt period and meet other conditions or the order will be reinstated, a judge said.
content: Donald J. Trump was released from a judicial order holding him in contempt of court on Wednesday, ending an embarrassing two-week period for the former president, whose business practices are under civil investigation by the New York state attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Gloria Parker, Maestra of the Musical Glasses, Dies at 100
description: She played many instruments and appeared on radio and television, but she was best known for the skill that led to a role in Woody Allen’s“Broadway Danny Rose.”
content: As the title character in his film “Broadway Danny Rose” (1984), Woody Allen is a hapless talent agent known for his stable of weird, hard-to-book novelty acts: a blind xylophone player, a stuttering ventriloquist, a balloon folder — and Gloria Parker, who plays music by rubbing her moistened fingers along the rims of 28 crystal wine glasses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Only a third of Americans were worried about the pandemic in April, even as new cases rose, a new poll finds.
description: The survey, from Gallup, was conducted between April 15 and April 23, at a time when new cases were increasing after plummeting from highs seen during the winter Omicron surge.
content: About 31 percent of American adults said in April that they were “very” or “somewhat worried” about contracting the coronavirus, according to a new Gallup poll released on Wednesday, indicating that about two-thirds was not as worried, even as new confirmed cases began to rise steadily across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Elon Musk Has Bigger Plans Than Just Letting Trump Back on Twitter
description: America’s richest man tries to halt the liberal retreat from dynamism.
content: “I strongly supported Obama for President,” Elon Musk tweeted late last month, part of the spree of ideological comments accompanying his continuing takeover of Twitter, “but today’s Democratic Party has been hijacked by extremists.” Around the same time, he set the social-media platform ablaze by reposting a cartoon showing a stick figure comfortably on the center-left in 2008 redefined as a right-wing bigot by 2021 because the left-wing stick figure had raced way off to the left. Then this week, he expressed the same kind of thought in the abbreviated style for which the site is famous: “Twitter obv has a strong left wing bias.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Closer to a Vaccine for Young Kids
description: A study found Moderna’s vaccine elicited a strong immune response in young children.
content: June is shaping up to be a big month for vaccines for young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: A Garden Is Planned for the Obama Presidential Center
description: Slated to open in Chicago in 2025, the Eleanor Roosevelt Fruit and Vegetable Garden will honor the legacies of two first ladies.
content: The Obama Presidential Center, opening on the South Side of Chicago in 2025, has announced plans for a fruit and vegetable garden, a nod to the former first lady Michelle Obama’s focus on healthy eating. But its name honors another “trailblazer and humanitarian” who amplified “her husband’s agenda,” Eleanor Roosevelt, said Valerie Jarrett, the chief executive of the Obama Foundation. The planned garden will incorporate produce that is culturally significant to Chicago and the experience of Black people in the United States, and the crops will be used for food service at the center. The center is working with the Emerald South Economic Development Collaborative, which turns vacant lots into community gardens on the South Side. “One of the goals of the presidential center is to not just educate people on the President and Mrs. Obama’s legacy, but also to help people learn and take action into their own lives,” Ms. Jarrett said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Jim Pillen upends a Trump-backed rival to win Nebraska’s G.O.P. primary for governor.
description: Mr. Pillen, a University of Nebraska regent backed by the state’s departing governor, won a tight three-way race that included a scandal-plagued candidate endorsed by Donald Trump.
content: Jim Pillen, a University of Nebraska regent backed by the state’s powerful Ricketts political machine, has won the Republican primary for Nebraska governor, defeating a scandal-marred millionaire who had the backing of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Diana Nguyen, Jessica Cheung, Rob Szypko, Paige Cowett, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: A Post-Roe America, Part 2: The Abortion Providers
description: People working in abortion clinics describe the likely effects on patients if the constitutional right to a termination is struck down.
content: This episode contains descriptions of sexual violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Wheeler
title: Festival Devotees Migrate East
description: After a two-year hiatus, the Robot Heart party, normally held during Burning Man, made its return to glory and debut in the Big Apple.
content: A young man sporting elf ears and a pink beard danced shirtless to trance music. A crowd of people sipped Liquid Death, a new water brand marketed at festivals, as they shimmied and swayed, striking up conversations with strangers. Bystanders sat on grassy hills for a bird’s-eye view, taking in the colorful scene with intrigue. In a corner, a woman tested out a “sensory experience” chair, wearing a virtual-reality headset as her high-tech chair vibrated vigorously. Candy-scented clouds traveled from vape to mouth to air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Boyer-Dry
title: They Have Sold Pot for Years. Now They Want to Go Legal. Can They?
description: For “legacy” cannabis entrepreneurs, becoming a taxpaying, regulation-observing business has its challenges.
content: “I was always known as the guy that loved cannabis,” said Lou Cantillo, who grew up selling it to friends in Coney Island. That love came with a cost: when he was a teenager, he said he was chased and roughed up by a cop for smoking in the stairwell of his building, one of several encounters with the police around that time. But despite the risks, Mr. Cantillo kept selling as an adult, even during his brief career as a boxer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Stevenson
title: America and Its Allies Want to Bleed Russia. They Really Shouldn’t.
description: The war was dangerous enough before the West’s shift to a more expansive strategy.
content: The war in Ukraine has entered a new phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Which Way to the Stage’ Review: Theater Buddies, With Claws Out
description: In her new comedy, Ana Nogueira spins zippy fun out of a fairly conventional story about a friendship strained by resentment.
content: If you have ever fantasized about casting your favorite musical or ranked the actresses who have played Mrs. Lovett, chances are you will be familiar with Jeff and Judy. You might even be them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario
title: In the Trenches of Eastern Ukraine, Combat Becomes a Vicious Dance
description: In some villages along the front, Ukrainian and Russian soldiers face off at close quarters, sometimes within eyesight of one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Bill to Guarantee Abortion Rights Fails in Senate
description: Republicans used a filibuster to thwart the bill, but Democrats hoped the high-profile failure of their legislation would help them at the polls in November.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats tried and failed on Wednesday to push forward legislation to guarantee abortion rights nationwide, as Republicans and one Democrat in the Senate blocked an effort to enshrine the landmark Roe v. Wade precedent in federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: If There’s a Loud Fight About Roe, ‘Centrist America Will Just Turn Down the Volume’
description: What a reversal of Roe v. Wade might mean at the ballot box.
content: Abortion, it almost goes without saying, is a singularly fraught issue. Pew Research describes the complexity in a May 6 report, “America’s Abortion Quandary”: “A majority of Americans say abortion should be legal in all or most cases, but many are open to restrictions; many opponents of legal abortion say it should be legal in some circumstances.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Leonid Kravchuk, First President of an Independent Ukraine, Dies at 88
description: Days after his election, he signed a multinational agreement that formally declared the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
content: Leonid Kravchuk, who as the first popularly elected president of Ukraine shepherded it out of the collapse of the Soviet Union and signed off on giving up the country’s nuclear arsenal, died on Tuesday. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: A Sci-Fi Writer Returns to Earth: ‘The Real Story is the One Facing Us.’
description: Kim Stanley Robinson, one of the most acclaimed living science fiction writers, is done with deep space narratives. His focus now is on solving real problems — like climate change.
content: Last fall, the science fiction writer Kim Stanley Robinson was asked to predict what the world will look like in 2050. He was speaking at the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Glasgow, and the atmosphere at the summit — billed as the “last, best hope” to save the planet — was bleak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: His Report of Abuse Drew Ridicule at First. Years Later, a Jury Listened.
description: Alex Harrison sued his school district for negligence after his high school tennis coach molested him. The case landed him back at the courthouse where he’d first told his story years earlier.
content: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. — Alex Harrison waited a dozen years for one more chance to be believed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Aaron Judge Takes Home Run Lead With Walk-Off Against Toronto
description: Judge is the first major leaguer to 10 homers this season. The Mets, meanwhile, beat the Nationals after a rodent interrupted the action.
content: Aaron Judge hit a mammoth three-run drive in the ninth inning for his first walk-off home run in the major leagues to give the Yankees a 6-5 comeback victory over the Toronto Blue Jays on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross, David F. Gallagher and Anna Schaverien
title: The Pushback on E.S.G. Investing
description: Calls to rein in investing based on environmental and social principles are growing louder.
content: While speaking about energy policy in Texas yesterday, former Vice President Mike Pence, a potential 2024 Republican presidential contender, said he wanted to “rein in” E.S.G., or investing based on environmental, social and governance principles. He is not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Haitian Gang Leader Is Charged With Abducting American Missionaries
description: Prosecutors said Joly Germine directed the kidnapping operations of the 400 Mawozo gang, including the negotiations for the release of volunteers with Christian Aid Ministries.
content: WASHINGTON — A leader of a notorious street gang responsible for abducting 17 people tied to an American-based missionary group in Haiti last year was indicted by a federal grand jury on Tuesday on charges of conspiracy to commit hostage taking, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Child care benefits could help ease the worker crunch, an advocacy campaign says.
description: A survey by McKinsey & Company and Marshall Plan for Moms found that few workers had access to child care benefits, but most mothers said such benefits would make them more likely to accept a job.
content: Almost half of mothers with young children who left the work force cited child care as a reason for the move, according to a survey released Wednesday, and 69 percent of women looking for a job said child care benefits could sway their decision on where to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Newsom Offers Tax Breaks for Companies in Anti-Abortion States
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s plan to attract Texas and Florida businesses punctuates the battle between liberal and conservative states after a leaked Supreme Court draft opinion.
content: SACRAMENTO — Underscoring the nation’s widening divide as the U.S. Supreme Court seems poised to overturn the constitutional right to abortion, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Wednesday proposed a series of tax incentives explicitly aimed at recruiting employers from states that restrict reproductive and L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Benzel
title: Cutchogue, N.Y.: An Appealing Alternative to the Hamptons
description: The Suffolk County hamlet attracts buyers with walkable beaches, low-key restaurants and good schools. But finding a home there has never been harder.
content: The North Fork of Long Island unfurls eastward from Riverhead for 30 miles, with each hamlet marked by signs on the two thoroughfares, Routes 48 and 25. Travelers get little more than a glimpse as they pass by: a modest retail strip, a garden center, a steepled white church, a red brick schoolhouse, a fire station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Jesse McKinley
title: 4 Summer Election Days? New York Faces Chaos in Voting Cycle.
description: Representative Tom Reed is resigning, Representative Antonio Delgado is taking a new job, and New York’s redistricting process is up in the air, muddying the election schedule.
content: To understand the chaos upending New York’s election season, consider the plight of Marc Molinaro, the Dutchess County executive trying to run for Congress as a Republican somewhere near his home in the Hudson Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Don’t Be Fooled. It’s All About Women and Sex.
description: What’s the difference between a woman and a sea turtle? The Senate wants to know.
content: When I was back in high school — a Catholic girls’ school in Cincinnati at the beginning of the sexual revolution — our religion class covered the abortion issue in approximately 45 seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Club for Growth Starts Ad Blitz for Kathy Barnette in Pennsylvania Senate Primary
description: Running for Senate on a shoestring, the conservative commentator has pulled into contention against Dr. Mehmet Oz and David McCormick. What can she do with $2 million in ads?
content: After months of a bruising television ad war between Dr. Mehmet Oz and David McCormick and their allies, the relatively shoestring campaign of Kathy Barnette, a conservative commentator showing surprising strength in the polls, will receive a late boost in the Republican primary for Senate in Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: #VanLife
description: Does living in a van while traveling the country or the world appeal to you?
content: Have you seen the social media posts about #VanLife, in which people live out of their vehicles while traveling to wonderful places? Does that kind of life appeal to you? Why or why not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins, Boryana Dzhambazova and Nanna Heitmann
title: Once Best Friends, Bulgaria Takes a Stand Against Russia
description: Bulgaria has imposed economic sanctions on Russia, offered to repair broken military equipment for Ukraine and expelled Russian diplomats.
content: SHIPKA, Bulgaria — A week after Russia invaded Ukraine, Moscow’s ambassador to Bulgaria climbed a snowy mountain pass to honor czarist-era Russian soldiers who died there fighting for Bulgarian independence in the 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: The Most Famous Girl at the Waffle House
description: The singer-songwriter Ethel Cain has an elaborate vision of becoming a different kind of pop star. She’s doing it from rural Alabama.
content: DALEVILLE, Ala. — About 25 minutes north of the Florida border, near the mouth of a U.S. Army post and not much else, sits a simple brick home with wood paneling, open windows and a silver pickup truck out front.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Her Job Is a Walk in the Park’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about a Brooklyn dog walker. Then, they will interview someone in their community who has an interesting job.
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times in general. Learn more and tell us what you think here.

title: As the war fuels inflation, Biden plans to address rising prices and global shortages.
description: President Biden and the U.S. secretary of agriculture are expected to visit a farm in Illinois on Wednesday at a moment of deep concern about rising food prices and the availability of food in poorer parts of the world. Mr. Biden is expected to discuss how Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is raising food prices and how U.S. farmers can help alleviate global food shortages, according to the White House.

description: A selection of books published this week.
content: LOST LAD LONDON, VOL. 1, by Shima Shinya. (Yen Press, paper, $15.) In this graphic novel by the co-writer of the “Star Wars: The High Republic: The Edge of Balance” manga series, a Scotland Yard detective and a college student try to solve a murder on the London Underground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell
title: In the Shadow of a Cornish Castle, a Vegetarian Feast for Beltane
description: The couple behind the British interiors brand House of Hackney had a group of similarly sustainably-minded friends over to mark the ancient Celtic festival.
content: In the summer of 2018, while on holiday in Cornwall, in the southwest of England, Frieda Gormley and Javvy M. Royle, the married founders of the British interiors brand House of Hackney, happened upon Trematon Castle, whose gardens were open to the public for the season. Stepping onto the nine-acre estate of the Norman motte and bailey structure, which was built by Robert, Count of Mortain, in 1068 following the Battle of Hastings, they were instantly charmed. The palm- and acanthus flower-accented formal grounds that encase the home on three sides give way to apple orchards and untamed woodlands that slope down toward a creek, and from the lawn at the top of the hill the pair could see the River Lynher and, beyond it, the port city of Plymouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Operation Mincemeat’ Review: A Bland Hash
description: In this World War II drama from Netflix, a team of spies uses a vagrant’s corpse to outwit the Nazis.
content: Hundreds of thousands of British soldiers died fighting in World War II. “Operation Mincemeat,” directed by John Madden, tells the real-life story of one man drafted into the war effort after death — or rather, it tells the story of the men who conscripted him. In this bizarrely celebratory tale, the titular “mincemeat” is a troubling figure, weighing heavy on the conscience as the men who’ve enlisted him engage in petty infighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bob Lanier, a Dominant Center of the 1970s and ’80s, Dies at 73
description: Playing for the Detroit Pistons and the Milwaukee Bucks, he held his own against titans of the era like Wilt Chamberlain, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Willis Reed.
content: Bob Lanier, who as a center for the Detroit Pistons and Milwaukee Bucks in the 1970s and ’80s parlayed a deft left-handed hook shot, a soft midrange jumper and robust rebounding skills into a Hall of Fame career, died on Tuesday in Phoenix. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Where Have All the Liberals Gone?
description: Francis Fukuyama’s new book joins several from recent years in defining liberalism and arguing for its continued relevance.
content: Last week, I had the surreal experience of reading my way through a stack of high-toned books about liberalism when news trickled out that a conservative majority on the Supreme Court was preparing to overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: House Hunting in the United Arab Emirates: A Solar-Powered Palace in Dubai
description: In the Persian Gulf city, 50,000 new residences are expected to be completed by year’s end, which should keep a check on soaring prices.
content: This six-bedroom house is one of 189 clustered like petals around green space in the Dahlia section of Al Barari, a 351-acre oasis and eco-friendly community about 20 miles from the Persian Gulf in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Police Arrest Former Bishop in National Security Case
description: Cardinal Joseph Zen, 90, was among three held for their work with a legal aid group that helped protesters and that officials accuse of colluding with foreign powers.
content: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police arrested three prominent activists on Wednesday, including a retired bishop and a pop star who were leaders of a legal aid organization now under investigation for suspected violations of the city’s strict national security law, a lawyer for the group said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Man Who Many Democrats Wish Would Not Run
description: Representative Tom Suozzi could be re-elected to Congress. But he is running for governor instead.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at Representative Thomas Suozzi, a centrist Democrat who is giving up his House seat to try to unseat another centrist Democrat, Gov. Kathy Hochul. We’ll also look at plans to renovate Penn Station and redevelop the surrounding neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Assessing the Claims in the Alito Draft Opinion Overturning Roe
description: In the leaked draft, Justice Samuel Alito made assertions about fetal development, abortion procedures and international laws that were disputed or omitted context.
content: The leaked draft opinion suggesting the Supreme Court is poised to overturn Roe v. Wade cited claims frequently made by opponents of abortion. The opinion, written by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., at times presents those assertions as indisputable facts while omitting context and counterarguments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Gleyber Torres Powers Yankees Past Blue Jays
description: Torres drove in all five runs for the Yankees. The Guardians, meanwhile, had their game postponed by a coronavirus outbreak.
content: Gleyber Torres sent a fastball soaring, started jogging toward first base and raised his right arm about the time a young boy in the first row of the right field short porch caught the ball on the fly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: From Addiction to … Aviation? Tobacco, an Unexpected Fuel for the Future

author: By Mark Landler
title: The Ukraine War’s Economic Toll Is Testing the West’s Unity Against Russia
description: Russia’s president is calculating that Western leaders will tire before he does of a protracted struggle in Ukraine, especially if the price is turbocharged inflation and energy shortages.
content: LONDON — The West united against Russia’s war on Ukraine more swiftly and solidly than almost anyone had expected. But as the war settles into a prolonged conflict, one that could rumble on for months or even years, it is testing the resolve of Western countries, with European and American officials questioning whether the rising economic toll will erode their solidarity over time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Nearly a third of Ukraine’s jobs have been lost amid the war, U.N. labor agency says.
description: The report highlights the grim economic toll of Russia’s aggression and the challenges that lie ahead for Ukraine and other nations.
content: Russia’s war has caused colossal losses in employment and income for Ukrainians, destroying nearly a third of all jobs in the country and threatening the loss of millions more if the conflict continues, the United Nations’ labor organization said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: In a first, a Russian soldier will stand trial in Ukraine on war crimes charges.
description: A 21-year-old Russian soldier is accused of following orders to shoot an unarmed cyclist four days into Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: A 21-year-old Russian soldier accused of shooting a civilian on a bicycle and leaving him dead on the side of the road will be the first Russian service member to stand trial in Ukraine for war crimes since the invasion, Ukraine’s prosecutor general said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Little Kids’ Sleep Is So Wild
description: Keeping your head on the pillow may be a learned behavior.
content: The other night my children slept at their grandparents’ apartment. They both had trouble sleeping, which is not unusual when they’re away from home, and my poor parents ended up sharing beds with the kids. The little one ended up kicking her granddad in the back all night long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: The Pandemic Has Been Punishing for Working Mothers. But Mostly, They’ve Kept Working.
description: When it came to who lost jobs, education mattered much more than gender, a broad new analysis found.
content: For mothers during the pandemic, the usual push and pull of work and family life has felt more like a tug of war. Yet despite concerns that they would quit their jobs en masse, most succeeded in keeping them, two new data analyses show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Ben Hubbard
title: Trailblazing Palestinian Journalist Killed in West Bank
description: Ms. Abu Akleh, 51, a Palestinian American reporter who was killed in the West Bank on Wednesday, was a household name across the Middle East.
content: JERUSALEM — Shireen Abu Akleh originally studied to be an architect but could not see a future for herself in the field. So she decided to go into journalism instead, becoming one of the best-known Palestinian journalists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: What J.D. Vance’s Primary Win Says About Populism and Resentment in the G.O.P.
description: Two conservative writers discuss Trumpism’s appeal in the Republican Party and what the rise of J.D. Vance foreshadows for the midterms.
content: May is chock-full of primary elections, and they are starting to provide a picture of how deeply the G.O.P. is entrenched in Trumpism. J.D. Vance, a 37-year-old venture capitalist and the author of the acclaimed memoir “Hillbilly Elegy,” won the Republican Senate primary in Ohio — with the endorsement of Donald Trump. The rise of Vance paints a telling portrait of how the G.O.P. is evolving in its appeal to its conservative base. Vance eagerly sought Trump’s endorsement and praise. Does it mean that the party is becoming a “populism of tribal loyalty,” as suggested by one of today’s guests?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Can the West Stay United?
description: The war’s economic toll is testing Western solidarity.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Lufthansa Apologizes After Jewish People Were Barred From Flight
description: Passengers said that after landing in Germany, more than 100 people were blocked from boarding a connecting flight to Hungary, after a handful of passengers disobeyed a mask requirement.
content: Lufthansa Airlines apologized this week after passengers traveling from New York City to Hungary said they were blocked from boarding a connecting flight in Germany because they were Jewish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Overdose Deaths Continue Rising, With Fentanyl and Meth Key Culprits
description: New data shows a surge in overdose deaths involving fentanyl and methamphetamine. Overall, the nation saw a 15 percent increase in deaths from overdoses in 2021.
content: WASHINGTON — After a catastrophic increase in 2020, deaths from drug overdoses rose again to record-breaking levels in 2021, nearing 108,000, the result of an ever-worsening fentanyl crisis, according to preliminary new data published on Wednesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Common Medications Can Prolong Back Pain When Overused, Study Says
description: A clinical trial will be needed to verify the research, which offered a warning about taking steroids or nonprescription drugs for weeks on end.
content: The very treatments often used to soothe pain in the lower back, which the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says is the most common type of pain, might cause it to last longer, according to a new study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Do You Feel About ‘Nepotism Babies’?
description: Young people are discovering that their favorite actors are the children of already-famous parents. Are you bothered by how Hollywood passes down power?
content: Have you ever discovered that one of your favorite TV or movie stars had famous parents? If so, you may have come across a so-called nepotism baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Long After Blockade, Canada’s Truckers Have a Political Champion
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau condemned the protest as illegal. Now some of his key opponents are embracing it.
content: OTTAWA — Canadians were shocked when a group of truckers rolled their rigs into the nation’s capital earlier this year, paralyzed the downtown area for weeks and demanded that the government lift all pandemic-related restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Nikola Jokic of the Denver Nuggets Wins Second M.V.P. Award
description: A 6-foot-11 center, Jokic stands out among N.B.A. big men with his ability to score from inside and outside and bang the boards while finding open teammates.
content: Nikola Jokic, the Denver Nuggets center with the passing touch and shooting stroke of a guard, won the N.B.A.’s Most Valuable Player Award for the second consecutive season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Lasers, Fish-Skin Bandages and Pain-Free Vaccines: The Winners of Our 3rd Annual STEM Writing Contest
description: From extraterrestrial plants to the psychology of color, students explain concepts from the world of science, technology, engineering and math.
content: Imagine a world where we can turn cancer-causing tobacco into a renewable energy source; where needles are virtually painless; where we can repurpose our own cells to reverse degenerative diseases; and where we can use lasers to discover buried ancient worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Why the Justice Department Is Unlikely to Investigate the Supreme Court Leak
description: The internal inquiry led by the court’s marshal has limited tools, but there are challenges to opening a criminal investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — After a leak of a draft opinion showed that the Supreme Court was poised to end women’s constitutional right to abortion, some Republicans and conservative commentators called for a criminal investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Alex Mooney defeats David McKinley, a House colleague, in a newly drawn district.
description: A Trump endorsement swung a primary between two Republican congressmen in West Virginia.
content: Representative Alex Mooney handily defeated a House colleague and fellow Republican, David McKinley, in a primary in West Virginia that again proved both the power of an endorsement by former President Donald J. Trump and the weight that right-wing ideology holds with Republican primary voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Fear and Loathing Return to Tech Start-Ups
description: Workers are dumping their stock, companies are cutting costs, and layoffs abound as troubling economic forces hit tech start-ups.
content: Start-up workers came into 2022 expecting another year of cash-gushing initial public offerings. Then the stock market tanked, Russia invaded Ukraine, inflation ballooned, and interest rates rose. Instead of going public, start-ups began cutting costs and laying off employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Rich
title: Everything You Thought You Knew, and Why You’re Wrong
description: A scientist and policy analyst examines the systems that rule our world, denounces easy solutions and makes the case for uncertainty.
content: HOW THE WORLD REALLY WORKS
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Surfside Condo Collapse Victims Reach $997 Million Settlement
description: The settlement, which includes insurance companies, developers and other defendants, comes nearly a year after the tragedy killed 98 people.
content: MIAMI — Families of the victims of the collapse of the Champlain Towers South condominium in Surfside, Fla., that killed 98 people last year have reached a $997 million settlement to compensate them for their staggering losses of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: The E.U. will no longer recommend that masks be required for air travel.
description: The decision came as countries across the bloc were loosening restrictions in response to the current rates of vaccination and naturally acquired immunity.
content: The European Union will no longer recommend that member states require face masks on planes and in airports, two E.U. agencies announced on Wednesday, ending a guideline that had been in place for nearly two years as countries across the bloc lift Covid restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Dry Nasal Covid-19 Vaccines: A Pain- and Needle-Free Alternative
description: We are honoring the top eight winners of our Student STEM Writing Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Amy Ge.
content: This essay, by Amy Ge, 15, from The Governor’s Academy in Byfield, Mass., is one of the top eight winners of The Learning Network’s third annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,564 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Farley
title: Looking to Help Ukrainian Refugees? A ‘Voluntourism’ Guide
description: At least 12 million Ukrainians have been displaced by war. Nearly 6 million of them have fled to neighboring countries. How to volunteer in Krakow, Poland, and other places.
content: You could say my path to spending two weeks volunteering to help Ukrainian refugees in Krakow, Poland, began almost three years ago, when I went to Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, to write a travel article for The New York Times. The many Ukrainians I met were friendly, generous and went out of their way to help me. I left the country with a special place in my heart for them. And so, once war broke out there in February, I wanted to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Air Pollution Can Mean More, or Fewer, Hurricanes. It Depends Where You Live.
description: Smog from factories and cars has led to more storms in the Atlantic Ocean, but fewer in the Pacific. A new study explains why.
content: Global warming can affect hurricanes, in part because a warmer ocean provides more energy to fuel them. But it’s not the only factor in play: A study released on Wednesday confirms that, for the frequency of hurricanes, the effects of particulate air pollution are even greater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: PGA Tour Denies Golfers Waivers for Saudi-Backed Tournament
description: The tour has made it clear it will suspend players who defect to Greg Norman’s rival LIV Golf series, which is set to make its debut in England next month.
content: The PGA Tour has sternly refused to grant its membership the ability to play in the inaugural event of a rival Saudi-backed golf tour, which will make its debut next month outside London. The move, announced in a memo to tour members Tuesday night, was hardly a surprise — the PGA Tour is protecting its business — but in the most gentlemanly of sports, it exposed uncharacteristic rancor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in Florida, Pennsylvania and California
description: A midcentury-modern showplace in Sarasota, a Victorian rowhouse in Philadelphia and a Tudor Revival home in Sacramento.
content: The owner, who bought the property in 2018, has spent four years renovating it, adding a new roof, plumbing and HVAC systems. It serves as a showcase for midcentury style with an extensive collection of period-appropriate furniture, décor and appliances, as well as paint colors and wallpaper throughout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
title: India’s Top Court Suspends Colonial-Era Sedition Law
description: The law has been used to quash dissent and is not in tune with the times, the court said. Its action does not overturn the law, though, only Parliament can do that.
content: NEW DELHI — India’s top court directed the government on Wednesday to suspend a colonial-era sedition law that critics say has been abused for decades to shut down dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: N.Y.P.D. Should Discipline 145 Officers for Misconduct, Watchdog Says
description: The civilian oversight group made the recommendations after reviewing hundreds of complaints against police tactics during the racial justice protests following the murder of George Floyd.
content: Amid a swell of protests following the murder of George Floyd two years ago, a flurry of videos showing officers behaving aggressively with protesters — charging into crowds and at times punching or pushing people to the ground — prompted a flood of complaints about their behavior to an independent oversight agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Gallagher
title: The Purple Tree Gods of Los Angeles Return
description: The annual splash of jacaranda flowers is here. But what’s the story behind the tree that many love, and others not so much?
content: Every year, about this time, Stephanie Carrie, who started the Trees of L.A. Instagram account, gets the same question: “Someone said, ‘I saw a tree the other day, Stephanie. I wanted to ask you what it was?’ I said, ‘Did it have purple flowers? It’s a jacaranda.’ And I’m like, Oh, my god, how many years have you lived in Los Angeles?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russian advances in eastern Ukraine.
content: More than two months into the war in Ukraine, Russia is making some significant territorial gains, even as its invasion has been marred by poor planning, flawed intelligence, low morale and brutal, indiscriminate violence against civilians. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis
title: What’s Behind Fashion’s Rediscovery of the Bare Midriff?
description: It might be that in exposing the waist, designers are also revealing their hope for a bolder and better future.
content: IN EVERY ERA, a bombshell emerges. Marilyn Monroe helped usher in the sexual revolution of the 1960s. In the ’90s, Pamela Anderson became a symbol of the internet’s pornographic potential. And at the beginning of 2022, we got Julia Fox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Good News About Food Delivery
description: Delivery apps are making fresh food available to millions who couldn’t have easily gotten it otherwise.
content: I’ve written about the downsides of companies that bring groceries or prepared food to our doors, like Instacart and Uber Eats. App-based fresh food deliveries take a toll on our neighborhoods and impose punishing demands on workers.
